info.caption: This map, based on data from UNEP/GRID-Europe, reflects the maximum tropical storm intensity experienced at each point around the globe between 1970 and 2009, as indicated by wind speed. Intense winds drive large waves which can damage coral reefs and result in coastal flooding. Storm intensity has increased since 2009, in conjunction with rising ocean temperatures.

attributes.name: Historical Cyclone Intensity
attributes.description:
### Overview  
  
The Historical Cyclone Intensity dataset estimates the maximum tropical storm intensity experienced at each point around the globe between 1970 and 2009, as indicated by wind speed. Intensity is described via the Saffir-Simpson hurricane wind scale, meaning each value represents the "strongest" cyclone within each 1 arc minute grid cell during that time.

  
  
Hurricane‐force winds can destroy buildings and fling dangerous debris. However, storm surge and large waves produced by hurricanes pose the greatest threat to life and property along the coast. A storm surge is an abnormal rise of water generated by a storm's winds.The destructive power of storm surge and large battering waves can result in loss of life, buildings destroyed, beach and dune erosion, and road and bridge damage along the coast. Storm surge can span hundreds of miles of coastland and can travel several miles inland. In estuaries and bayous, salt water intrusion endangers public health and the environment. More powerful storms can lead to stronger winds and larger surges. Tracking historical cyclone events can help in estimating the level of threat posed by storms in a given region.

  
  
Observations of historical cyclone events are sparse globally, which led researchers to estimate storm characteristics using [a parametric model created by Greg Holland](https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1980)108%3C1212:AAMOTW%3E2.0.CO;2). These modeled results are based primarily on [IBTrACS](https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/ibtracs/) v02r01—the most complete global set of historical tropical cyclones available—but United Nations Environment Programme/Global Resource Information Database-Geneva(UNEP/GRID-Geneva) reconciled a wide range of datasets into a common framework. By applying modeling equations to this unified historical archive, UNEP/GRID-Geneva built a homogeneous structured cyclone database with first level basic
meteorological data and spatial data. This global cyclone database makes possible
post-analysis of historical cyclone events, such as the dataset presented here.
  
  
### Methodology  
  
This dataset is derived from a geospatial database of historical tropical storms, which includes estimates of wind speeds and other properties across space and time. This database drew upon [IBTrACS](https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/ibtracs/) v02r01 as well as tropical cyclone data from Regional Specialised Meteorological Centres (RSMCs) and the Tropical Cyclone
Warning Centres (TCWCs) of the World Meteorological Organisation. This database was constructed using the [Cyclone Database Manager](https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.117.6313&rep=rep1&type=pdf) created by UNEP/DEWA/GRID-Geneva.

  
  
Geospatially complete characterizations of historical tropical storms were extrapolated from historical observations using [a parametric model created by Greg Holland](https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1980)108%3C1212:AAMOTW%3E2.0.CO;2), which was selected on the basis of universal recommendation from all polled tropical cyclone specialists. Data compilation and GIS processing were executed by UNEP/GRID-Europe as part of the production of the [Global Assessment Report on Risk Reduction (GAR)](https://gar.undrr.org/).

  
  
For the full documentation, please click on the “Learn more” button or see the [source methodology](https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.117.6313&rep=rep1&type=pdf) for the underlying cyclone database.  
  
### Additional Information  
  
Resource Watch displays the [IBTrACS historical tropical cyclone tracks](https://resourcewatch.org/data/explore/dis015a-Hurricane-Tracks) on which this historical intensity dataset is largely based.

  
  
Resource Watch shows only a subset of the dataset. For access to the full dataset and additional information, click on the “Learn more” button.
  
  
### Visualizing the Data  
  
Our team reformatted this dataset before displaying it on Resource Watch. See the documentation on how Resource Watch retrieved the data on [Github](https://github.com/resource-watch/data-pre-processing/tree/master/ocn_005_historical_cyclone_intensity).  
  
### Disclaimer  
  
Excerpts of this description page were taken from the source metadata.

info.technical_title: Tropical cyclones wind speed buffers footprint 1970-2009
info.cautions:
- According to the author of the core parametric model, the measured pressures observations are more conservative and error prone than wind observations, but the reliability of these data is uncertain.
  
  
 -The sustained maximum wind speed is less reliable than the values of central pressure and this
is probably due to the differences in measurement, not defined by the provider.
  
  
 - The most important uncertainty is the radius of the maximum wind speed. The creators were forced to estimate this, since relevant data were not to be found.
